awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Determining the molecular mechanisms of the Arabidopsis circadian clock: the role of the pseudo-response regulators
awd_abstract_narration: The circadian clock is a self-sustained biological oscillator that enables organisms to both anticipate environmental changes and to coordinate different aspects of their physiology. In plants, the circadian clock is necessary for optimal growth and survival and regulates a wide range of physiological processes such as flowering and photosynthesis. The long-term goal of Dr. Farre's laboratory is to understand the design principles of circadian clocks as well as the role of the clock in plant growth and development. In particular, this project will help elucidate the molecular role of the morning expressed pseudo-response regulators PRR7 and PRR9 in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana using molecular and biochemical approaches. These studies will define not only the molecular function of the PRRs in the circadian oscillator but also the direct role of clock components in the control of physiological responses in plants. Due to the architectural similarities between circadian networks in different organisms, this work will complement the analyses in other systems and advance our understanding of circadian clocks and their mechanisms to impact a large number of processes ranging from biomass production to human circadian disorders. Dr. Farre will also establish a two-year program at Michigan State University for students aimed at becoming secondary biology teachers to gain experience in scientific inquiry in a laboratory setting and to teach laboratory courses. Students will do a research internship in the Farre laboratory where they will work on their own research project associated with this award as well as establish a teaching unit that can be used in a high school class. Students will also be able to practice their teaching skills as teaching assistants of an undergraduate laboratory course.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

The goal of this proposal was to investigate the function of pseudo-response regulators (PRRs) in Arabidopsis thaliana. PRRs are conserved components of the circadian clock in plants and algae and we have shown that the PRR gene family expanded during the evolution of land plants. There are five PRRs in Arabidopsis which are expressed at different times of day. Our work was focused on PRR7 and PRR9, which are expressed during the first half of the light period and play partially redundant roles in the regulation of circadian rhythms.

We have shown that PRR7 and PRR9 are transcriptional regulators associated with target promoters in vivo. Previous studies had shown that PRR7 and PRR9 are involved in cold, drought, growth and photoperiod control of flowering time. Through this project, we have shown that PRR7 and PRR9 modulate these processes by directly regulating the transcription of master regulators of these physiological responses. In addition, we have also demonstrated that PRR7 and PRR9 also affect plant responses to oxidative stress. PRRs associate with chromatin in vivo but lack a canonical DNA binding domain. Compiling our own and publicly available data we have shown that all Arabidopsis PRRs associate with the same promoter regions in common target genes. We also demonstrated that a G-box like DNA promoter element is necessary but not sufficient for transcriptional regulation by PRRs.

We had initially hypothesized that PRR7 was involved in protection of plants against UV-B stress. Although further studies did not confirm PRR7’s role in this response we have shown that the circadian clock modulates UV-B signaling throughout the day. The clock genes LUX ARRHYTHMO, EARLY FLOWERING 3 and EARLY FLOWERING 4, directly regulate the expression of several UV-B induced genes leading to time of day dependent changes in UV-B mediated transcription. Moreover, we also showed that the sensitivity of plants to UV-B stress is regulated by both the circadian clock and light signals leading to higher resistance against UV-B damage during the day than during the night.

In summary, this work not only increased our understanding of the particular functions of clock components but also showed that the circadian clock in plants is tightly integrated with most other signaling networks, providing a mechanistic explanation for the wide range of responses under circadian control.

Broader Impacts:

The PI developed a Teaching & Research program for undergraduate students aiming at becoming K-12 teachers. Science teachers play a key role in developing the scientific understanding of the public. However, most teacher training programs do not require research experiences for science teachers. The two undergraduate students in this program spent 10 weeks in the laboratory over the summer and were involved in a research project.  In addition, students developed and tested a laboratory teaching unit and mentored other undergraduate students in a laboratory course at Michigan State University. Self-reports from the pre-service teachers indicated that the program helped them increase their understanding of the scientific process and of the career opportunities in science, as well as help them transmit the importance and excitement of science to their own students. This program continues as part of a different NSF award.
